child.pub-comments: The name is Fleming's, but Christopher Ehret and Joseph Greenberg both agreed that the Omotic branch split from the rest first, and most scholars either reject Omotic as Afroasiatic (e.g. Newman 1980), or see it as distinct from the rest. Thus all except Omotic would be a subgroup, and for this we use Fleming's name

child.pub-comments: Introduced in the 8th century following the Arab conquest of Spain, Arabic became heavily influenced by the Romance dialects of the Iberian peninisular, and evolved into a distinct colloquial language with numerous Romance loanwords. It became the vehicle of a lively literary and musical tradition, and is found in numerous texts. It continued to be spoken in Spain until the sixteenth century, and songs in this dialect are still sung by North African Andalusī musicians. In medieval times, Ibn Khaldūn described it as the third major non-nomadic Arabic variety, alongside Maghrebī and Mashreqī. It is characterized by strong fronting of low vowels ("'imāla") and stress-based phonology. (Information in part from Lameen Souag)

child.pub-comments: The oldest version of the Aramaic language. Inscriptions found in Syria. Standard Syrian or Western is the name used for inscriptions from c. 850 - 700 BC found in the vicinity of Aleppo in Syria. Fakhariya is used to describe the dialect found in a single inscription on the upper Habur. Mesopotamian refers to brief texts found on clay tables in Iraq, and shows Akkadian influence. Samalian is the name used for the idiosyncratic dialect used at Zincirli in Turkey in ten inscriptions of Bar-Rakkab, King of Sam'al, the Neo-Hittite kingdom also called Ya'udi. These are the earliest texts found in an Old Aramaic dialect, and date from the second half of the 8th century B.C. 10-8th cent. BC.

Rubin belives that Imperial Aramaic should be classifed into two periods: Early Imperial Aramaic (700-550 BC) and Imperial Aramaic (550-200 BC). The most widespread language during the period of the New Assyrian empire, and the chancellery language of the Persian Empire. This language appears in the Old Testament of the Bible in five places: Ezra 4:8-6:18, Ezra 7:12-26, Daniel 2:4-7:28, Jer. 10:11 and Gen. 31:47. 7-4th centuries BC.

The most widespread language during the period of the New Assyrian empire, and the chancellery language of the Persian Empire. This language appears in the Old Testament of the Bible in five places: Ezra 4:8-6:18, Ezra 7:12-26, Daniel 2:4-7:28, Jer. 10:11 and Gen. 31:47. 7-4th centuries BC.

How Rubin wants Neo-Aramaic dialects treated is not clear. He deals with them almost as if they were a single group, but since he gives no name to the node above, he clearly does not want to claim they are indeed a group. In addition he explicit says that they are not descended from earlier known dialects, but that they fall into the Western and Eastern groups that the earlier dialects did. We therefore treat the neo-Aramaic dialects as simply descending from the earlier groupings, and not as a coherent group in and of themselves.

From the communication with Charles Häberl: Assyrian Neo-Aramaic (aii) is a religious rather than linguistic category, and the referent of "Assyrian" changes from individual to individual (sometimes it just means members of the Church of the East, sometimes it also refers to Syrian Orthodox, sometimes it even includes Chaldean and Maronite Catholics, among others). According to Charles Häberl, the term should be dropped or limited to Urmia Northeastern Neo-Aramaic (which includes the most commonly used so-called "Assyrian" dialects).

child.pub-comments: How Rubin wants Neo-Aramaic dialects treated is not clear. He deals with them almost as if they were a single group, but since he gives no name to the node above, he clearly does not want to claim they are indeed a group. In addition he explicitly says that they are not descended from earlier known dialects, but that they fall into the Western and Eastern groups that the earlier dialects did. We therefore treat the neo-Aramaic dialects as simply descending from the earlier groupings, and not as a coherent group in and of themselves.

child.pub-comments: An ancient language of Northern Africa. An offshoot of Phoenician, this was the language of Carthage and its empire, and developed from the variety of Phoenician brought to North Africa by colonies from the Phoenician city of Tyre. In the period of the Roman empire, the language was gradually supplanted by Latin, but remained spoken in rural areas until the end of the Roman period. The language appears in two versions: Punic, the older version of the language, and Neo-Punic, the later version. 1st Millennium BC - 600 AD.

child.pub-comments: The evidence for this language consists of three monumental inscriptions found at Zinjirli (ancient Sam'al) in southeastern Turkey. Though some consider it a dialect of Aramaic, it does not share the innovations which characterize this group, such as the postposed definite article -ā, the loss of the n- stem, and the nominal feminine plural in -ān. It is therefore best considered a separate branch of Northwest Semitic. 820-730 BC.
child.publications: Rubin, Aaron D. 2007. The Subgrouping of the Semitic Languages, Language and Linguistics Compass, vol. 2, 79-102.

child.pub-comments: It is not clear what to do with this language and its dialects. Ethnologue lists it as a cluster of dialects, but Newman lists Jimi as being a dialect of Guruntum, Jimo as being equivalent to Zumu, and Jimjimum (which may be the Jimjimen the Ethnologue lists) as being possibly a dialect of Matakam. For the while, this is left simply as a member of the Bata (Biu-Mandara A8) group.
